The facility also has an established Emergency Response Brigade that routinely undergoes advanced training needed to facilitate a quick response to an emergency and minimize the impact of the event to personnel, to the process, and to the environment. The EPC is reviewed and updated, as appropriate, based on changes at the facility or new information obtained from coordination activities, emergency response exercises, incident investigations, or other available information, and ensures that affected employees are informed of the changes.

The overall emergency control program for the Geismar Ethylene Plant is coordinated with the Ascension Parish and Iberville Parish Local Emergency Planning Committees (LEPC). This coordination includes periodic meetings which are also attended by local emergency state officials, local government officials, local emergency response agencies, and representatives from other industrial facilities. The Geismar Ethylene Plant has communications capability with appropriate emergency response organizations (e.g., sheriff's office, Geismar Area Mutual Aid, complex emergency brigade, etc.) via radio and telephone. This communication system provides a means for quick notification and, if needed, coordination of mutual aid response as well as notification to the public.  In addition to periodic LEPC meetings, the Geismar Ethylene Plant conducts periodic emergency drills on various scenarios to ensure a timely and effective response in the event of an actual emergency.

(F)	 Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The Geismar Ethylene Plant routinely reviews the safety programs in place at the site and implements any identified changes that will improve the overall safety program and enhance protection of all personnel onsite and in the community.  Currently, there are no planned changes outside of these routine reviews.

The Geismar Ethylene Plant also complies with the Maritime Transportation Security Act (MTSA) which is designed to protect U.S. ports and waterways from a terrorist attack. In accordance with 33 CFR Part 105, the facility maintains a security plan which outlines the policies, practices, and guidance in place to reduce the number and mitigate the impact of security incidents at the facility which may result in a significant loss of life, environmental damage, transportation system disruption, or economic disruption.

(D)	 Five-Year Accident History 

Events at the Geismar Ethylene Plant over the last five years were reviewed.  There were no accidental releases from covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

(E)	 Emergency Response Program Information

The Geismar Ethylene Plant maintains a written Emergency Control Plan (EPC) which includes procedures for safely responding to a release of a regulated substance, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released. These procedures are intended to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment by addressing all aspects of emergency response, including proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans including accounting for personnel after evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public as needed, and post incident cleanup and decontamination requirements. Executive Summary

In accordance with 40 CFR 68.155, NOVA Chemicals Olefins LLC (NOVA) has prepared the following Executive Summary to be incorporated into the Risk Management Program Plan for the Geismar Ethylene Plant located in Geismar, LA within Ascension and Iberville Parishes.

(A)	 Accidental Release Prevention and Response Policies:

The Geismar Ethylene Plant has a long-standing commitment to protect employees, the community and the environment. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety and environmental consequences in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our processes. Our policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of hazardous materials. However, if a release does occur, our trained emergency response personnel will respond to control, contain, and mitigate the release.

(B)	 Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances:

The Geismar Ethylene Plant is subject to the requirements of 40 CFR Part 68, Chemical Accident 
 prevention Provisions. The facility produces ethylene, propylene, crude butadiene and debutanized aromatic concentrate (DAC) from ethane and propane feedstocks. The following regulated chemicals identified in 40 CFR 68.130 are present in quantities above the respective threshold: 
-	Feedstocks: Ethane, Propane
-	Products: 1,3-Butadiene, Propylene, Ethylene 
-	Treatment: Chlorine 

(C)	 General Accidental Release/Chemical-Specific Prevention Programs Steps

The Geismar Ethylene Plant has a robust prevention program which is aligned with the elements from EPAs Risk Management Program (RMP) and OSHAs Process Safety Management (PSM) Standard.
